text: This is a list of Minnesota Wild award winners. ==League awards== ===Team trophies=== The Minnesota Wild have not won any of the team trophies the National Hockey League (NHL) awards annually — the Stanley Cup as league champions, the Clarence S. Campbell Bowl as Western Conference playoff champions and the Presidents' Trophy as the team with the most regular season points. ===Individual awards=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Individual awards won by Minnesota Wild players and staff2014–2015 Minnesota Wild Team Guide, p.148 ! scope="col" |Award ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |Description ! scope="col" |Winner ! scope="col" |Season ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy |rowspan="2" | Perseverance, sportsmanship and dedication to hockey | || |rowspan="2" | |- | || |- ! scope="row" | Jack Adams Award | Top coach during the regular season | || | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | King Clancy Memorial Trophy | rowspan="2" | Leadership qualities on and off the ice and humanitarian contributions within their community | || | rowspan="2" | |- | || |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | Roger Crozier Saving Grace Award |rowspan="2" | Goaltender with the best save percentage | || |rowspan="2" | |- | || |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | William M. Jennings Trophy |rowspan="2" | Fewest goals given up in the regular season | ||rowspan="2"| |rowspan="2" | |- | |} ==All-Stars== ===NHL First and Second Team All-Stars=== The NHL First and Second Team All-Stars consists of the top players at each position as voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers' Association. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+ Minnesota Wild selected to the NHL First and Second Team All-Stars ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Selections ! scope="col" |Season ! scope="col" |Team |- ! scope="row" | | |1 | |2nd |- ! scope="row" | | |1 | |1st |} ===NHL All-Rookie Team=== The NHL All-Rookie Team consists of the top rookies at each position as voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers' Association. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+ Minnesota Wild selected to the NHL All-Rookie Team ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Season |- ! scope="row" | | | |} ===All-Star Game selections=== The National Hockey League All-Star Game is a mid-season exhibition game held annually between many of the top players of each season. Fourteen All-Star Games have been held since the Wild entered the league in 2000, with at least one player chosen to represent the Wild in each year except 2001 and 2002. The All-Star game has not been held in various years: 1979 and 1987 due to the 1979 Challenge Cup and Rendez-vous '87 series between the NHL and the Soviet national team, respectively, 1995, 2005, and 2013 as a result of labor stoppages, and 2006, 2010, and 2014 because of the Winter Olympic Games. Minnesota has hosted one of the games. The 54th took place at Xcel Energy Center. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Minnesota Wild players and coaches selected to the All-Star Game |- !scope="col" | Game !scope="col" | Year !scope="col" | Name !scope="col" | Position !scope="col" class="unsortable"| References |- ! scope="row" | 51st |2001 |No Wild selected |— | |- ! scope="row" | 52nd |2002 |No Wild selected |— | |- ! scope="row" | 53rd |2003 | | | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2"| 54th | rowspan="2"|2004 | | | rowspan="2"| |- | | |- ! scope="row" | 55th |2007 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 56th |2008 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 57th |2009 | | | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | 58th |rowspan="2" |2011 | | |rowspan="2" | |- | | |- ! scope="row" | 59th |2012 | (Did not play) | | |- ! scope="row" | 60th |2015 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 61st |2016 | | | |- ! scope="row" rowspan="3" | 62nd |rowspan="3" |2017 | | |rowspan="3" | |- | | |- | | |- ! scope="row" | 63rd |2018 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 64th |2019 | | | |- ! scope="row" | 65th |2020 | | | |} ==Career achievements== ===Hockey Hall of Fame=== The Minnesota Wild have not had any players or personnel who have been enshrined in the Hockey Hall of Fame. Jacques Lemaire, the team's head coach from 2000 to 2009, was inducted in the Players category in 1985., retrieved July 2, 2015 ===Lester Patrick Trophy=== The Lester Patrick Trophy has been presented by the National Hockey League and USA Hockey since 1966 to honor a recipient's contribution to ice hockey in the United States. This list includes all personnel who have ever been employed by the Minnesota Wild in any capacity and have also received the Lester Patrick Trophy. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Members of the Minnesota Wild honored with the Lester Patrick Trophy ! scope="col" |Individual ! scope="col" |Year honored ! scope="col" |Years with Wild ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" | | |2000–2008 | |} ===Retired numbers=== The Minnesota Wild have retired one of their jersey numbers. Prior to the Wild's first home opener on October 11, 2000, the team retired number 1 "in honor of the fans who helped bring back the NHL." Also out of circulation is the number 99 which was retired league-wide for Wayne Gretzky on February 6, 2000. {| class="wikitable sortable" width="75%" |+Minnesota Wild retired numbers2014–2015 Minnesota Wild Team Guide, p.154 ! scope="col" |Number ! scope="col" |Player ! scope="col" |Position ! scope="col" |Years with Wild as a player ! scope="col" |Date of retirement ceremony ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |References |- ! scope="row" |1 |Wild Fans |— |— |October 11, 2000 | |} ==See also== *List of National Hockey League awards ==References== Minnesota Wild award
title: List of Minnesota Wild award winners
